attack you on the ranch. It's time to get some
definitive info logged on these bad boys. The
Blaze Phoenix is rumored to be one, but no one
has come forward with detailed info on that yet.

Here are the ones we know:
Torridon (Ducken): Sun_Bath
Oboro (Zan): KILL'em
Liarosa (Garu): GNIKNIOL

These are suspected:
Blaze (Phoenix): HeAt_Up

I know the two I got I was in class A at the
time. Can anyone who has gotten Blaze step
forward and talk about details? Has anyone gotten
any other breeds in random attacks? I feel I get
attacked more when my monster is tired does
anyone agree?

Open topic, bounce ideas, test theories, let's
unlock some breeds!

All I want for Christmas is a Cinder Bird... =)

By GoldenBoy on Wednesday, January 8, 2003 - 03:39 pm:

BUMPalicious

Just a few pointers on getting attacked:

Tired monsters are more likely to get attacked.

Week one of a month has a better shot at an attack.

Class of monster seems to matter for the specials.

Summertime has a higher rate of strays.

Just my observations, ymmv.


PS I'd like to hear from someone who has gotten a Liarosa (Garu/SP-U) particularly, what monster did you have, and what rank was it?

By GoldenBoy on Thursday, January 9, 2003 - 08:58 am:

I'm sure it will still attack whether Emperor's has been beaten or not. I am of the opinion that Master class is master class (the little crown icon you get after S official) as far as the monster is concerned. I heartily recommend the reload procedure.

Also to hearten you, my phoenix lived to 5yr, but I was quite good to him. Also there is fairly conclusive evidence that any monster at Master rank can get attacked by Blaze.

By GoldenBoy on Thursday, January 9, 2003 - 10:14 pm:

By GoldenBoy on Friday, January 10, 2003 - 10:19 am:

Stat hits for being tired:

A little tired: 6% with no ACC hit
Tired: 12% with a 6% ACC hit

All stats take a hit, ACC less than the others.
On Second thought I think part of the ACC hit is mitigated by my Eagle Eye trait.

I have yet to experiment with the more extreme ranges of tiredness.

By GoldenBoy on Thursday, January 16, 2003 - 02:53 pm:

I have a new theory. The only thing it replaces from what I said earlier is the summertime idea.

I think a monster has an attack counter. The longer you go without a stray fight, the higher the chance for it. I am deliberately reloading if I get attacked and I now get attacked almost every week regardless of tiredness.

So now my advice to get attacked changes a little.
Reload if you get attacked and proceed s few more months. When the frequency of attacks goes up more, get tired save and reload. I'm in master class and the monster has yet to get hit by any rares, so I dtill think my 1rare/rank holds true.

By GoldenBoy on Saturday, January 25, 2003 - 10:12 pm:

New Attacking Monster!

Burns- #202 Ifrit
422/422/434/421/465/389
Gave password: rdWFburn

I was raising my Whitehound, Fluffy. I deliberately got my attack counter up pretty high (see above post for how) as I approached Class A. I had to fight the B Offical twice, to make it through and land in wk1 Nov without an attack. I saved a reloaded. On my second reload I was attacked and it was Burns.

I feel that this is the method to get some of the remaining Legends (FeaterGold and Pitbocor, possibly Devibianc and Kali too). I don't think this will work for any other rank than Class A but I could be wrong.

This also strengthens my suspicion that some of the Attacking monsters depend on the breed you are raising. xswzaq could very well have been correct about Cinder Bird. I am going to flip a coin as to whether I go after Liarosa or Cinder Bird next.

I was raising a Lionel I got attacked in Class A with a high attack counter, according to pattern. Ignore my post about certain monsters in certain classes. See Friends and Foes for a Table (coming soon). See below for my latest theory on what rares are available.

By GoldenBoy on Thursday, February 6, 2003 - 08:04 am:

Ok here's a real, reasoned, experiment with some decent results. Hopefully it will be helpful, and make some sort of sense.

Theory There is a hidden Attack Counter in the game. The longer your monster goes without a random attack, the higher it's chances to get attacked. This was a test to verify its existence, and begin to determine, in a rough way, how much it increments each week.

The Test I used a monster that had developed a fairly high chance to get attacked (Class S Ragnaroks). In an attempt to get FeaterGold I had avoided attacks (see Notes) to a point where I could barely proceed without getting attacked. Here are the steps I took, and the results are in a table below:
1) The Dragon was fully rested, and I reloaded 101 times and marked the results. On the 101st reload I fought the battle and defeated the Stray.
2) I trained, then saved, then used the Overload trick (nevertired method) 4 times to get the dragon back to energetic.
3) Then I reloaded 100 times and marked the results.
4) Then I proceeded with a normal training schedule for 37 weeks. I avoided one attack that came after about 4 months. This was an arbitrary amount of time, basically I stopped when I had maxed DEF and LIF.
5) Lastly I reloaded 100 times and marked the results.

Results
WeekAttackNo Attack%
-1604160
001000
37247624

% chance increase per week= .65%

Notes and Flaws

1)this probably isn't enough reloads to be statistically valid. Also I will proceed another few months untill I reach one year, and test again to see if the number holds up.

2) the biggest flaw, one I just realized, is that week -1 and week 0 were in the same month. I seriously doubt the game allows for 2 attacks in the same month. If I test this again I will either do it on week4 then week1 of the next month, or wait one full calendar month.

3) avoiding attacks- by this I mean if I was attacked I simply reloaded from my most recent save, never more than 3 weeks.

4) There are certain factors that add to your chances. Like Tiredness, or certain weeks (like week 1 or Tournament weeks). If I can come up with a way to test these additions I will. I already have a test planned to check tiredness.

5) I have no idea if the Attack counter varies by breed. I will try my test again someday, with a different monster.

6) what it all boils down to: This is of use when you are seeking a Rare Attacker. The longer you wait the better your shot. For the Attackers that become available in Class A I found that taking the first fight in Class D, then training and advancing as quickly as possible timed itself out well. I ended up hitting Class A with and Attack chance of 50% and thats really as much as you need. Once you get to Class A with a chance like that it often takes only a few reloads to get the monster you seek.

By Kurasu Soratobu on Sunday, February 23, 2003 - 02:38 pm:

I can't make any comments about the special wild monsters, but I can confirm the 'monster counter'. I had a monster in E-class for over a year, getting stats. When I finally moved it to D-class, I had 6 monster fights in the first week (reloaded every loss, and each time I finished the E-class battle, I came into another monster attack). Then, the first week I didn't, I had one in the second week that I actually managed to defeat.

By GoldenBoy on Wednesday, February 26, 2003 - 08:40 pm:

Look at step three in the notes section above, Dmonsters.

1) Play for a while if you get attacked.
2) Give up the battle then reload.
3) Continue training or sleeping.
4) Repeat this until it is almost impossible to go further without getting attacked.

When the attacks come on almost every reload, simply reload until you get attacked by the monster you want.
